children.value: French Grammar Glossary active voice when the subject performs an action.
a word that modifies a noun or a pronoun.
a word that modifies a verb, an adjective, or another adverb.
a word or group of words to which a relative pronoun refers.
small words that are generally classified as adjectives. They indicate that a noun or noun substitute will follow.
verb one of two elements needed to form a compound tense. Also called a helping verb.
J'ai aller chez Tom, Je suis allé
the numbers we use for counting.
words that are the same or similar in both French and English.
a mood that expresses what a subject would do under certain circumstances.
a mood that expresses what a subject would have done under certain circumstances.
the action of changing the ending of the verb so that it agrees with the subject noun or pronoun performing the task.
être: je suis, tu es, il est, ils sont, nous sommes, vous êtes
an article that indicates a specific person or thing: the house.
an adjective that precedes nouns to indicate or point out the person, place, or thing referred to: this, that, these, or those.
a pronoun that stands alone to indicate or point out the person or thing referred to.
answers the question whom or what the subject is acting upon and may refer to people, places, things, or ideas. May be a noun or pronoun.
a word or phrase used to show surprise, delight, incredulity, emphasis, or other strong emotion.
words that are spelled the same or almost the same in both languages but have entirely different meanings and can be different parts of speech.
a tense that expresses what the subject will do or is going to do or what action will or is going to take place in a future time.
a tense that expresses what the subject will have done by a future time.
indicates whether a word is masculine or feminine.
a particular word or expression whose meaning cannot be readily understood by either its grammar or the words used.
a verb form used to give commands or make requests.
a past tense that expresses a continuous, repeated, habitual or incomplete action, situation, or event in the past that was going on at an indefinite time or what used to happen in the past.
expresses any, no, other, certain, some, each, the same, several, some, all, etc.
refers to persons and objects not specifically identified.

expresses any, no one, none, other(s), other one(s), certain one(s), some, each one, everyone, the same one(s), one, several, someone, anyone, some, a few, something, anything, nothing, all, everything, anything, etc.
a pronoun used to emphasize a fact and to highlight or replace nouns or pronouns.
a verb tense that states a fact.
answers the question to or for whom the subject is doing something and refer only to people. May be a noun or pronoun.
the basic "to" form of the verb.
the act of asking a question by inserting a rising inflection at the end of the statement.
the reversal of the word order of the subject pronoun and the conjugated verb in order to form a question.
je peux voir la menu => puis-je voir le menu?
a word used to name a person, place, thing, idea, or quality.
an article asking for an indefinite quantity (part of a whole: some or any).
a tense that expresses an action or event completed in the past.
a past tense that occurs primarily in formal, literary, and historical writings expressing a completed action.
when the subject is acted upon.
a tense that expresses what the subject would have done under certain conditions.
a verb form expressing an action that has occurred in the past.
a tense that expresses what the subject had done.
a word used to relate elements in a sentence: noun to noun, verb to verb, or verb to noun/pronoun.
a verb form ending in -ing that expresses an action that is taking place.
a tense that expresses what is happening now.
a word that is used to replace a noun (a person, place, thing, idea, or quality).
a verb that shows that the subject is performing the action upon itself.
a pronoun that joins a main clause (a clause that can stand alone) to a dependent clause.
the noun performing the action of the verb.
a mood expressing wishing, emotion, doubt, denial.
a word that shows an action or state of being.
